articles.headline: As Debt Limit Threat Looms, Wall Street and Washington Have Only Rough Plans
articles.snippet: A default would most likely rattle markets and carry big risks, no matter how the Federal Reserve and Treasury try to curb the fallout.
articles.abstract: A default would most likely rattle markets and carry big risks, no matter how the Federal Reserve and Treasury try to curb the fallout.
articles.lead_paragraph: With days to go before the United States bumps up against a technical limit on how much debt it can issue, Wall Street analysts and political prognosticators are warning that a perennial source of partisan brinkmanship could finally tip into outright catastrophe in 2023.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Joe Rennison

articles.headline: FTX Executives Expressed Concern Over Use of Customer Funds, Documents Show
articles.snippet: Documents obtained by The New York Times provide new details about the discussions among FTX’s top leaders before the cryptocurrency exchange collapsed in November.
articles.abstract: Documents obtained by The New York Times provide new details about the discussions among FTX’s top leaders before the cryptocurrency exchange collapsed in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks before FTX collapsed, a top executive at the cryptocurrency exchange met with its founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, to express a gnawing concern.

articles.headline: In Hunt for FTX Assets, Lawyers Locate Billions in Cash and Crypto
articles.snippet: Lawyers for FTX have identified cash and digital assets that would go toward repaying customers and lenders of the collapsed exchange.
articles.abstract: Lawyers for FTX have identified cash and digital assets that would go toward repaying customers and lenders of the collapsed exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months after FTX filed for bankruptcy, lawyers for the once high-flying cryptocurrency exchange have begun to identify and put a value on its assets, as they determine how much they will be able to recover to repay lenders and customers who lost billions of dollars.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Pentagon Sends U.S. Arms Stored in Israel to Ukraine
articles.snippet: Israeli officials had initially expressed concerns that the move could damage its relations with Russia.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials had initially expressed concerns that the move could damage its relations with Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is tapping into a vast but little-known stockpile of American ammunition in Israel to help meet Ukraine’s dire need for artillery shells in the war with Russia, American and Israeli officials say.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous, Ronen Bergman, John Ismay and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: ‘The Ability to Say Yes’ to Stories Long Neglected on the Screen
articles.snippet: People of color are financing a number of movies at the Sundance Film Festival focused on elevating underrepresented voices.
articles.abstract: People of color are financing a number of movies at the Sundance Film Festival focused on elevating underrepresented voices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like so many anxious filmmakers the week before the start of the Sundance Film Festival, Erica Tremblay was tucked inside a dark room in Los Angeles, prepping the final sound mix for her feature debut, “Fancy Dance.”

articles.headline: ‘I Don’t Want to Die’: Fighting Maternal Mortality Among Black Women
articles.snippet: A St. Louis doula program, part of a nonprofit that received funding in the $1.7 trillion federal budget bill, looks for solutions in a benefit largely associated with affluent white women.
articles.abstract: A St. Louis doula program, part of a nonprofit that received funding in the $1.7 trillion federal budget bill, looks for solutions in a benefit largely associated with affluent white women.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Mo. — Tara Ervin will never forget the week her sister Kelly died.

articles.headline: How the Netherlands Is Taming Big Tech
articles.snippet: Dutch privacy negotiators have spurred major changes at Google, Microsoft and Zoom, using a landmark European data protection law as a lever.
articles.abstract: Dutch privacy negotiators have spurred major changes at Google, Microsoft and Zoom, using a landmark European data protection law as a lever.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2021, privacy consultants working for two Dutch universities issued a critical report card on Google’s education apps, a set of classroom tools like Google Docs that are used by more than 170 million students and educators worldwide.

articles.headline: Microsoft to Lay Off 10,000 Workers as It Looks to Trim Costs
articles.snippet: The job cuts, which amount to less than 5 percent of the company’s work force, are its largest in roughly eight years.
articles.abstract: The job cuts, which amount to less than 5 percent of the company’s work force, are its largest in roughly eight years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Wednesday became the latest addition to a growing list of big technology companies that have announced plans to lay off employees because of overhiring during the pandemic and worries about the economy.

articles.headline: Amid Fight Over Judiciary, Israeli High Court Orders Netanyahu Minister Removed
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled that Aryeh Deri, a close ally of the prime minister who was convicted of tax fraud, should be removed from his posts, as the government tries to restrict the courts’ powers.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that Aryeh Deri, a close ally of the prime minister who was convicted of tax fraud, should be removed from his posts, as the government tries to restrict the courts’ powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel’s Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that a politician convicted of tax fraud was not fit to serve as a senior minister in Benjamin Netanyahu’s new right-wing coalition, a move likely to accelerate a looming showdown between the government and the judiciary over control of the country’s highest court and one that could destabilize the government.

articles.headline: G.O.P. in Talks With Networks About Debates, and Even CNN Is Included
articles.snippet: Conversations between R.N.C. officials and television executives signal that the contours of the Republican nominating contest are shaping up.
articles.abstract: Conversations between R.N.C. officials and television executives signal that the contours of the Republican nominating contest are shaping up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite a field of candidates who regularly bash the news media and a continuing tussle with the Commission on Presidential Debates, Republican leaders sat down last week with television executives in New York and posed a question:
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
